awd_titl_txt: Coastal SEES Collaborative Research: Climate change impacts on the sustainability of key fisheries of the California Current System
awd_abstract_narration:
The area off the California coast supports productive commercial and recreational fisheries such as squid, sardine, and lobster that are important to human cultures, economies, and livelihoods. Climate change is expected to alter the oceanic system and contribute to changes in fish populations that will directly affect fishers' profits and behavior, as well as managers' actions in setting limits on harvest. This collaborative Coastal SEES study brings together oceanographers, fisheries scientists, economists, and social scientists to develop a better understanding of interactions among the climate and coastal ocean system, fish populations, fishers and fishing communities, and resource management. The research team includes state and federal scientists, and results will be shared with the resource management community. The project will support interdisciplinary training for undergraduates, graduate students, and postdoctoral scientists, and the investigators will participate in a number of public outreach activities. 

This Coastal SEES project assembles a diverse team of oceanographers, fisheries scientists, economists, and social scientists to develop new, integrated understanding of climate effects on coastal fisheries. The investigators will examine how fishing behavior, income, jobs distribution, and livelihood viability will be altered by climate change. The focus is on three key commercially harvested species that are known to respond to environmental change: Pacific sardine, California market squid, and California spiny lobster. Each of these supports an economically important fishery and represents a different type of organism in terms of marine habitat, latitudinal range, and time scale of response. The approach will include global climate model projections, regional ocean modeling, fisheries modeling, economics modeling, plus studies of management scenarios and fisher behavior. The goal will be to help develop sustainable management strategies under future climate scenarios given predicted ecological, social, and economic outcomes for these three fisheries.

por.por_cntn:
This project aims to understand the economic impact of climate change on fisheries within the California Current System (CCS). We have developed a multidisciplinary modeling procedure to estimate how climate-forced environmental and fisheries changes will alter fishing behavior and income. Based on the changes in stock size and range from those modeling results, we have constructed economic models that predict spatial variability of jobs and income, viable fishing regions, mobility of fishers, the economics of each target fishery, and wider economic effects on the region. Our products have yielded practical information that can improve policy decision-making to yield benefits for society. We have also communicated directly with fisheries managers to help inform current and future management efforts.

We first provide an empirical definition for the coastal pelagic species (CPS) fleet, which is crucial for the rest of the research project. The project utilized several databases and various variables, including vessel data, permit data, and landings data. Through our investigation, we conclude that a possible approach is to utilize the metric of the majority of revenue from CPS species (more than 50% of yearly revenue from CPS species) to define a vessel as a CPS vessel.  

We have analyzed CPS vessels' tendency to stay in the fishery and what factors influence this decision, emphasizing climate-driven factors. Our results indicate that high squid abundance increases the likelihood of remaining in the CPS fishery. For the biomass of the lower value species, such as pacific- and jack mackerel, we do not find any influence on vessel decision to stay/switch/exit the CPS fishery. Further, we find that high efficiency increases the likelihood of staying in the CPS fishery. The scale of the fishery is also important, where a large vessel with many fishing days has a higher likelihood of staying in the CPS fishery than a smaller-scale vessel. External factors, such as opportunities in other sectors, are also important for the decision to stay in the fishery. 

To characterize the specialization within each CPS fishing trip, we have analyzed a specialization/diversification index (BHI), capturing the degree that U.S. western coast vessels fishing for coastal pelagic species (CPS) specialize or diversify by harvesting multiple species on the same fishing trips. We find that the management group with the highest draft BHI index score is that of coastal pelagic species (CPEL), indicating the cleanest landings as measured by the index. On the other hand, the preliminary index result characterizes the groundfish fishery (GRND) as having the most mixed landings. While only 15% of all coastal pelagic species trips are mixed trips, mixed trips account for 82% of all groundfish trips.

Big data empirical techniques are deployed to estimate production functions for CPS fisheries. Investigating over 30 years of Paciﬁc Sardine, Market Squid, Paciﬁc Mackerel, Jack Mackerel, and Northern Anchovy catch, both standard LASSO and the method for Instrumental Variables LASSO are applied. We show that the big data techniques are eﬀective for both the endogenous and exogenous eﬀort case and may provide insights into which oceanographic and climate variables are relevant to ﬁsheries for diﬀerent species.

In addition, we investigate the economic consequences of extreme weather, particularly the impact of extreme weather on vessel inefficiency and production risk. This is done by estimating a stochastic production frontier model with flexible risk specification using commercial Pacific sardine fisheries, oceanic conditions, and weather data. Because of climate change, extreme weather is expected to increase. Without a turn in the tendency, this implies that fishermen will be exposed to higher frequency and intensity of extreme weather events in the future. Since both wind and precipitation will increase the cost of operating at sea, the fishermen's income will be hampered by increased extreme weather events.
